Depending on your screen width you either see a tabbed view (< 480dp) or two panels side by side (≥ 480dp). The first tab or panel shows an edit area for variable and function symbols. The second one contains an edit area for new equations and also shows a list of all current equations.

string-array.name: eq_save
string-array.item: The import and save options are available in the overflow menu of the action bar (the three vertical dots at the far right end).

Import: import equational systems from .trs oder .xml files. Files from the local KBCV folder are shown as a list. By default this list contains at least the standard group-theory example, but also all other equational systems that you ever from KBCV saved.
Save: saves the current equational system to the local KBCV folder. A dialog will open where you have to enter a name for your file.

string-array.name: eq_symbols
string-array.item: Add: Pressing the + button opens a radial menu, where you can select the symbol you want to add. When adding a function symbol, you are also required to choose an arity after you selected a symbol.\nIf you want a symbol that is not contained in the list, use the button with the 3 dots (…) to open a dialog where you can enter a string that you want to use as symbol. The symbols that are shown in the radial menu by default can be changed in the settings.
Delete: Longpress the symbol you want to delete, this makes the symbol draggable and turns the + button into a trash symbol. Now drag and drop the symbol onto the trash.

string-array.name: eq_equations
string-array.item: Creating equations: At the bottom of the equations view the edit area is located. The edit area holds a list of all previously defined variables and function symbols as draggable buttons. By dragging and dropping a symbol into the designated dropzone that symbol will be added to the equation. For functions with an arity greater than zero, the appropriate number of dropzones will be created. Symbols can also be dragged onto other symbols and thereby overwrite that part of the equation.\nWhen an equation is finished, i.e., containing no more dropzones, you can either press the ADD button or drop the equation into the list of existing equations by dragging it up at the ≈ sign.

Editing and Deleting: You can select items in the list above the edit area and choose the desired action in the action bar. When choosing edit the equation will appear in the edit area at the bottom of the screen and you can start dragging different symbols onto it.

resources.string: Depending on your screen width you either see a tabbed view (< 480dp) or two panels side by side (≥ 480dp). The first tab or panel shows a list of all equations of the current equational system, the second one shows all rules of the current rewrite system.\nIn both views any number of items (equations or rules) can be selected and one of the inference rules of Knuth-Bendix completion can be applied to them, by using the appropriate action in the contextual action bar.

string-array.name: export_content
string-array.item: The export action is available in the overflow menu of the App Bar. The current term rewrite system will be exported as a TRS file to the KBCV folder in Documents.

string-array.name: gesture_content
string-array.item: Orient\n Rightswipe equation to orient it from left to right, leftswipe it to orient from right to left.
Simplify and Delete equation\nLongpress equation until it is draggable, drag it down and release it. This simplifies the equation as far as possible and then deletes it, if it has become trivial.
Deduce\nLongpress rule until it is draggable, drag it onto the → of another rule and release. This adds all critical pairs that exist between those two rules to the equational system.

Simplify, Compose, Collapse\nLongpress rule until it is draggable, drag it onto left- or right-hand side of another equation or rule. That term will be reduced with the rule, resulting in a Simplify, Compose, or Collapse action.

string-array.name: automatic_comp_content
string-array.item:
Select automatic completion in the App Bar. It will either:
 • succeed and find a complete rewrite system,
 • fail because it can not orient a specific equation,
 • stop because it reached the maximum number of rounds.
Either way the rewrite system that was reached during automatic completion will be displayed (whether it is complete or not).
The maximum number of rounds is initially set to 100 and can be modified in the settings.

string-array.name: check_content
string-array.item: After every application of Orient or Delete, the app checks automatically for completeness. A message will then be displayed at the bottom of the app. This behaviour can be changed in the settings.\nYou can manually check for completeness by selecting the action in the App Bar.

resources.string: Turn off the automatic completeness check that is by default performed after every Delete- or Orient-action. This may be useful when you want to perform as much of the completion process manually as possible.
By default the app will remember which overlaps have already been considered and won’t add those equations repeatedly. You can turn of caching to test your own ability of finding critical pairs.

Set the maximum number of rounds for automatic completion. An interesting option here is to set the number of rounds to 1. Then you can perform automatic completion round by round and view all intermediate equational systems and term rewrite systems.

Opens a dialog window where you can specify which variable symbols should be shown in the radial menu of the Equation Editor. Individual symbols have to be entered with a comma as delimiter, spaces being ignored. The maximum number of symbols that can be displayed in the radial menu is 6. Everything you enter after the sixth symbol will be ignored.

Opens a dialog window where you can specify which function symbols should appear in the radial menu of the Equation Editor. As with the variable symbols, characters can be entered into the edit dialog with a comma as delimiter and anything that exceeds the limit of six different symbols will be ignored.

We use the lexicographic path order (LPO) to determine whether an equation can be oriented into a rule, such that the resulting term rewrite system is still terminating. You can either provide the precedence for LPO yourself or leave it to the app, to figure out the necessary restrictions. This screen shows the ordering that is used at the moment to ensure the termination of the current term rewrite system. You can add, edit and delete rules as long as termination of the current rewrite system can be proved with this precedence.

Adding a rule to the precedence works similarly to adding equations. At the bottom of the Precedence screen an edit area is located. Inside is a list of draggable buttons of all available function symbols and a stub of a new rule with a dropzone at each side. Function symbols can be dragged onto the dropzones (and onto other function symbols) to create a new rule. You can add a finished rule to the precedence by either pressing the add button or dragging it up on the < sign.

To edit or delete an existing rule, you need to select it by tapping it and then choosing the appropriate action in the contextual action bar at the top of the screen. When selecting edit, the rule appears in the edit area and you can drag different function symbols onto the existing ones to change it.\nIf you to add a restriction that contradicts LPO termination, or if you trie to remove a rule that is needed for termination, the app will show an error message.

string-array.name: history_undo
string-array.item: The three activities Equation Editor, Completion, and Precedence, all feature undo and redo buttons in their respective action bars.
every orient, simplify, delete, deduce, compose, collapse in the completion screen

resources.string: Tapping the history entry in the Navigation Drawer opens a dialog showing all actions that were performed in the app since the last startup. Every entry is clickable and transforms the current equational system, symbols and rewrite system back to that state.
